awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Combining Heating And Radio Diagnostics On Natural AeronomY (CHARDONAY)
awd_abstract_narration:
The research will use the High-frequency Active Auroral Research Program (HAARP) facilities to artificially perturb the ionosphere using high-frequency radiation. This technique, known as ionospheric modification, stimulates responses in the ionosphere that can be investigated in the absence of the "clutter" accompanying natural excitation of the ionosphere by aurorae and high-energy solar events. The proposed efforts would re-open the HAARP observatory following its transition from military to civilian management at the University of Alaska. The planned work is also very well coordinated with measurements from an NSF-funded network of high-latitude radars. This proposal therefore represents a substantial opportunity to build infrastructure. The HAARP facility hosts an atmospheric radiation and radio science summer school, and so has the potential to draw in new graduate students.

The ionospheric modification technique allows properties such as temperature and density to be measured under highly controlled conditions. This information will used to study phenomena such as turbulence, diffusion, conductance, and polar mesosphere cloud physics. These processes all facilitate the transfer of energy from the solar wind through the magnetosphere, thermosphere and ionosphere (MTI) to the neutral atmosphere. Further understanding of this coupling is required in order to model and predict the response of the MTI system to explosive solar events, and the impact of this so-called ?space weather? on communication and navigation systems.

por.por_cntn:
Collaborative Research: Combining Heating And Radio Diagnostics On Natural AeronomY (CHARDONAY)

 

Collaborative Research: Combining Heating And Radio Diagnostics On Natural AeronomY supported research related to natural aeronomy. The main focus was using HAARP to perturb the ionosphere and use a variety of diagnostics to observe the response. The UAF portion focused on using the SuperDARN radars to observe the decay of artificially created ionospheric irregularities to deduce diffusion coefficients.

The award supported a three-year program that included 20 hours of HAARP operations each year, two thirds of which are allocated for the other participants in the collaboration (Dave Hysell of Cornell, and Wayne Scales of Virginia Tech). The budget also supported 0.11 months of the Principal Investigator?s time and one month of a research professional for programming.

The award was somewhat ill-timed for two reasons. First, there were only limited opportunities for HAARP campaigns because there were very few other funded researchers supporting the facility. The University of Alaska was heavily subsidizing the cost of maintaining the facility and could not afford to have campaigns without a critical mass of experimenters. In addition, the facility was under powered (60% of capacity) because of maintenance issues related to the transfer of ownership from the Air Force to UAF. Second, the solar cycle was near it?s minimum throughout the period of the grant, so ionospheric plasma densities were low enough that the facility could not generate frequencies in a range that could do significant heating. The lowest frequencies available to the facility are around 3 MHz. The F-region peak plasma frequency was below that level for much of the time when experiment campaigns were carried out. Because of the proposed research required operating the facility over a range of frequencies, many of the proposed topics could not be investigated. The experiments that were carried out had only limited success.

 

In the last year of the original period of performance, there was only one research campaign and peak plasma frequencies were so low at the time that we didn?t propose any CHARDONAY experiments.

 

In the end, we proposed changing the scope and focus of the project to support investigation of natural F-region irregularities. The change of scope was to use the remaining funds toward relocation of the Adak SuperDARN radar. That radar was severely damaged by high winds during a large storm. An insurance settlement for repair of the damages was received by the University of Alaska. We decided that because of the difficulty and expense of maintaining the system on Adak, the radar would be relocated rather than simply repaired. The funds from this grant were used toward support of construction at the new location. Part of the relocation effort was to remove the radar equipment from Adak, which was completed in late 2021. The cost of demolition and site restoration was significant, and consumed all of the remaining CHARDONAY funds.
